channel.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

Taharok:

@OP: You have no reason not to want two equal consecutive results. Having that is essentially random. If you take that away, I would start to argue your PRNG is not random, because there is always probability of getting the same number twice. You are making it less random by predictably removing one number for every iteration of the PRNG.

The distribution would be affected, but I don’t know if you can say that’s less random. (With my solution, the combination of results is uniformly distributed rather than the individual results, which is actually better in this case.)

Read full topic
item.source: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:6, topic:462878”]I’d say make one base RNG, and 2 RNGs, based with seeds generated from the base.

It wont make it impossible for collisions to occur, but it will make it highly unlikely.[/quote]

This is called non-uniform PRNG, and it still won’t guarantee nonconsecutive equality.

@OP: You have no reason not to want two equal consecutive results. Having that is essentially random. If you take that away, I would start to argue your PRNG is not random, because there is always probability of getting the same number twice. You are making it less random by predictably removing one number for every iteration of the PRNG.

Read full topic

use a real functional language
join me, hadyn
join me

PS

(def kill (range 2 (shuffle ["Davidi2" "Taharok" "Frell"]))) [/quote]

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:21, topic:462878”]You could also do this:

speakerIndex = r.nextInt(5);
listenerIndex = (speakerIndex + r.nextInt(4) + 1) % 5;

At first glance it may look obscure, but I personally think it’s the most elegant solution.[/quote]
Very nice

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

Variation:

bitches = %w=Davidi2 Taharok Frell=
bitches.shuffle!
bitches.freeze
[:pop, :lock, :drop].each { |orders| bitches.send(orders) unless bitches.frozen? } until not defined?(bitches)

item.source: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

Simple example:

import java.util.Random;
public class Main {
    private static final Random r = new Random();
    private static final String[] personList = {"lol" ,"wat", "wtf", "omg"};
    public static void main(String[] args) {
            for(int i = 0; i <= 10; i++) {
                    int[] pair = randPair(personList.length);
                    System.out.println("Hi " + personList[pair[0]] + ", I'm " + personList[pair[1]] + ".");
            }
    }
    private static final int[] randPair(int maxLimit) {
            int speakerIdx = r.nextInt(maxLimit);
            int listenerIdx = r.nextInt(maxLimit);
            do { listenerIdx = r.nextInt(maxLimit); } while (speakerIdx == listenerIdx);
            return new int[]{speakerIdx, listenerIdx};
    }
}

Read full topic
item.source: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:8, topic:462878”]Shit, sorry about the edit. Hit your post instead of mine >.<[/quote]rofl noob mod

zyle for demote

OT - You could just populate an arraylist with all of the possibilites, and then arraylist.remove(r.nextInt(arraylist.size()))

For a fully compilable example:

[code=java]
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Random;

public class Test {

static ArrayList<String> results = new ArrayList<String>();
static String[] personList = new String[]{"Bob", "Joe", "Sue", "Jeff", "David"};
static Random r = new Random();

public static void main(String[] args) {
	populateResults();
	printRandomResults();
}

static void populateResults() {
  int s = personList.length;
  for(int i = 0; i < s; i++) {
    for(int l = 0; l < s; l++) {
      if(l == i) continue;
      results.add("Hi "+ personList[l] +", I'm " + personList[i] +".");
    }
  }
}

static void printRandomResults() {
  for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    System.out.println(results.remove(r.nextInt(results.size())));
  }
}

}
[/code]Is this the best way? Probably not

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to make sure two random numbers don't equal each other?
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

use recursion

[code=java]private int[] getRandomIndicies(int maxValue) {
int[] values = new int[] { r.nextInt(maxValue), r.nextInt(maxValue) };

if (values[0] == values[1]) {
	return getRandomIndicies(maxValue);
} else {
	return values;
}

}[/code]
